results:
Based on the search results, I can provide information about "Brave New World" being banned in Ireland in 1932 and verification from Australian sources:

## Ireland Ban in 1932

The book was banned in Ireland in 1932 for its language, and for supposedly being anti-family and anti-religion. Multiple sources confirm this, with some providing additional details that the novel was first banned in Ireland in 1932 for anti-religion, anti-family, and blasphemous content.

## Australia Verification and Ban

The search results provide verification from Australian sources, specifically from the National Archives of Australia. Brave New World was published in 1932 by Chatto and Windus, London and was named a prohibited import on 12 October of that year. Only one other nation also banned Brave New World; Ireland missed the irony central to the novel to label it anti-religion, anti-family, and extremely blasphemous.

This Australian government source confirms that:
- Australia also banned the book in 1932 (on October 12th specifically)
- Ireland was the only other nation to ban it at that time
- The Australian perspective acknowledges that Ireland "missed the irony central to the novel"

Additional sources confirm that Australia quickly followed by censoring the book in the same year and that the novel was banned in Ireland and Australia in 1932, with the latter maintaining its censorship for five years.

The Australian National Archives source appears to be an official verification of both the Irish ban and Australia's own censorship of the book, supporting the claim about Ireland's 1932 ban for anti-religious content.
